review.title: RDF2Rules: Learning Rules from RDF Knowledge Bases by Mining Frequent Predicate Cycles
review.abstract: Recently, several large-scale RDF knowledge bases have been built and applied in many knowledge-based applications. To further increase the number of facts in RDF knowledge bases, logic rules can be used to predict new facts based on the existing ones. Therefore, how to automatically learn reliable rules from large-scale knowledge bases becomes increasingly important. In this paper, we propose a novel rule learning approach named RDF2Rules for RDF knowledge bases. RDF2Rules first mines frequent predicate cycles (FPCs), a kind of interesting frequent patterns in knowledge bases, and then generates rules from the mined FPCs. Because each FPC can produce multiple rules, and effective pruning strategy is used in the process of mining FPCs, RDF2Rules works very efficiently. Another advantage of RDF2Rules is that it uses the entity type information when generates and evaluates rules, which makes the learned rules more accurate. Experiments show that our approach outperforms the compared approach in terms of both efficiency and accuracy.

metadata.title: RDF2Rules: Learning Rules from RDF Knowledge Bases by Mining Frequent Predicate Cycles

sections.heading: 2. FREQUENT PREDICATE CYCLES
sections.text: In this section we first present some basics of RDF-KBs, then define the concept of frequency predicate cycles (FPCs) and discuss the relationship between FPCs and logic rules.

sections.heading: 2.1 RDF and RDF KB
sections.text: The Resource Description Framework (RDF) is a framework for the conceptual description or modeling of information in web resources. RDF expresses information by making statements about resources in the form of < subject > < predicate > < object >. The subject and object represent two resources, the predicate represents the relationship (directionally) between subject and object. RDF statements are called triples because they consist of three elements. RDF is a graph-based data model; a set of RDF triples represents an RDF graph in which nodes represent resources and directed depressions. There can be three types of nodes (resources) in an RDF graph: IRIs, letters, and blank nodes. An IRI is a global identifier of a resource, such as people, organization, and place; literals are basic values such as strings, data, and numbers, etc.

sections.heading: 3. FREQUENT PREDICATE CYCLE MINING
sections.text: The basic idea is to first find the most common predicate paths (FPPs) of the specified maximum length and then to determine the number of all possible predicate paths (i.e. predicate paths) is (2N) k. As an example, there will be 8 million 3-predicate paths if we have 100 predicate paths. Since supporting predicate paths takes the most time, we must dictate the search space of predicate paths if we want to find all FPCs in a reasonable time.

sections.heading: 4. RULE GENERATION AND EVALUATION
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 4.1 Generate Rules from FPCs
sections.text: As discussed in Section 2, an FPC with k predicates can generate k rules. Formally, the resulting jth rule for an FPC θ = (x1, p d1 1, x2, p d2 2,..., p dk k, x1) is that it can generate the following two rules: < x1, p di i, xi + 1 > < xj, p dj, xj + 1 > (2) For example, an FPC (x1, hasParent1, x2, hasChildren − 1, x1) can generate the following two rules: < x1, hasParent, x2 > < x2 > < x2, hasChildren, x1 > < x2, hasParent, x2 >.

sections.heading: 4.2 Add Type Information
sections.text: < x1, bornIn, x2 > < x1, bornIn, x2 > < x1, diedIn, x2 >. Based on this rule, if we already know that someone was born somewhere, then we can predict that this man died in the same place as well. But, if the entity that initiates x2 is a small town, the prediction of this rule is more prone to be wrong because most people would not stay in the same town in their entire lives. If the entity that initiates x2 becomes a country, the prediction will have a higher probability of being correct. Based on this observation, the following rule is more advantageous. < x1, bornIn, x2 > < x1, typeOf, typeOf, people > < x2, typeOf, typeOf, country > < x1, the.

sections.heading: 4.3 Rule Evaluation
sections.text: The level of support defined in Section 2 measures how often a pattern appears in the countries concerned. < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < < <

sections.heading: 5. RDF INDEXING FOR MINING ALGORITHM
sections.text: To ensure the efficiency of our approach, we suggest using an in-memory index structure in our mining algorithm to support the mining algorithm, rather than using existing RDF storage systems. Generally, there are three types of queries about the RDF graph in our mining algorithm: (1) The query of the first type is used to generate frequent 1-predicate paths in algorithm 1; (2) The second is used in the predicate path growth process; (3) The query of the first type is used to generate frequent 1-predicate paths in algorithm 1; and the second is used in the predicate path growth process to count the predicate paths and find predicate cycles. To support the above queries, our approach uses two indices, the predicate entity entity index and predict entity index entity entity entity entity prediction entity entity entity.

sections.heading: 6. EXPERIMENTS
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 6.1 Experiment Setup
sections.text: We evaluate our approach with respect to YAGO2 and DBpedia 2014. YAGO2 is an extension of YAGO that is automatically built from Wikipedia, GeoNames and WordNet. DBpedia is a large-scale RDF KB that is built by extracting structured content from the information contained in Wikipedia. Details of the data sets used are given in Table 1. Entity types of YAGO2 come from YAGO3 [13] (the latest version of YAGO), as Galárraga et al. have done in their work [8]. For DBpedia 2014, we use the data set of mapping-based properties, entity types come from the DBpedia ontology. The third column in Table 1 are the numbers of facts that exclude the rdf: type statements. For each KB used, one data set without an entity type is used, a data set without an entity type is generated, and the third column in Table 1 is the data set with an entity type, the &ltp is the old data type.

sections.heading: 6.2 Mining Efficiency Analysis
sections.text: The running time and number of learned rules are compared with those of AMIE, i.e. 2, 3 and 4. The experimental results are outlined in Table 2.0.

sections.heading: 6.3 Confidence Measure Evaluation
sections.text: We propose a new confidence measurement that predicts soft confidence in Section 4.3. Table 5 and Table 6 list some rules learned from AMIE + and RDF2Rules from YAGO2. Rules in Table 5 are the top 10 rules with the highest PCA trust, and rules in Table 6 are the top 10 rules with the highest soft trust. We find that the second and third rules in Table 5 dictate isPoliticianOf facts; as we discussed in Section 4.3, there may be many people who havingdiedIn and isLocatedIn relationships, but only a small number of them are politicians. Most predictions of these two rules would be wrong. Soft trust penalizes the above two rules and it is not in the top 10 list. To further evaluate the effectiveness of our new confidence measurement, we leave RDF2Rules and AMIE + learn rules from DBpedia KB.

sections.heading: 7. RELATED WORK
sections.text: As every year, so it is again this year.

sections.heading: 8. CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this paper, we propose a novel approach to learning rules: RDF2Rules for RDF KBs. Rules are learned by finding frequent predicate cycles in RDF diagrams. Furthermore, a new measure of confidence for evaluating the reliability of the broken rules is proposed. Experiments show that our approach exceeds the comparable approach in terms of both the quality of the predictions and the runtime.

sections.heading: 9. ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
sections.text: The work is supported by NSFC (No. 61202246), NSFC-ANR (No. 61261130588) and the Basic Research Fund for Central Universities (2013 NT56).

referenceMentions.context: INTRODUCTION Recently, a growing number of large-scale Knowledge Bases (KBs) have been created and published by using the Resource Description Framework (RDF), such as DBpedia [1], YAGO [24], and Freebase [2] etc.

INTRODUCTION Recently, a growing number of large-scale Knowledge Bases (KBs) have been created and published by using the Resource Description Framework (RDF), such as DBpedia [1], YAGO [24], and Freebase [2] etc.

INTRODUCTION Recently, a growing number of large-scale Knowledge Bases (KBs) have been created and published by using the Resource Description Framework (RDF), such as DBpedia [1], YAGO [24], and Freebase [2] etc.

These KBs contain not only huge number of entities but also rich entity relations, which makes them successfully used in many applications such as Question Answering [25], Semantic Relatedness Computation [11] and Entity Linking[22].

These KBs contain not only huge number of entities but also rich entity relations, which makes them successfully used in many applications such as Question Answering [25], Semantic Relatedness Computation [11] and Entity Linking[22].

These KBs contain not only huge number of entities but also rich entity relations, which makes them successfully used in many applications such as Question Answering [25], Semantic Relatedness Computation [11] and Entity Linking[22].
It is reported that the new version of YAGO used logic rules to deduce new facts from the existing ones [9].

Learning rules from KBs has been studied for years in the domain of Inductive Logic Programming (ILP) [18], but ILP approaches usually need negative facts of target relations and typically do not scale well on large-scale KBs.
have proposed a system AMIE for learning rules from RDF data [7].
Most recently, AMIE has been Extended to AMIE+ by a series of improvements to make it more efficient [8].

In [8], the authors do discuss adding types in rules, but how to automatically learn rules with types is not detailedly explained in the paper; and according to our experiments, the released AMIE+ tool can not learn rules with type information.
In order to evaluate rules under the Open World Assumption (OWA), AMIE [7] uses a PCA confidence measure, which is defined as Equation 4.
This assumption is also adopted in KnowledgeVault [6].
The PCA confidence works well for rules having function predicate in the rule heads, and also holds for predicates having high functionality [7].
Entity types of YAGO2 are obtained from YAGO3 [13] (the latest version of YAGO), as Galárraga et al.
did in their work [8].
According to the experimental results reported in [8], AMIE+ outperforms both AMIE and several state-of-the-art ILP approaches.
We just follow the method that is used in [8] to allow AMIE+ to learn rules with types, i.

Although ILP systems such as [17] are proposed to learn rules from only positive examples, the main problem with these approaches is the low efficiency when dealing with large-scale KBs.

proposed a tensor factorization method RESCAL [19] for relational learning; RESCAL represents entities as low dimensional vectors and relations by low rank matrices, which are learned using a collective learning process.
RESCAL has been applied to YAGO and it can predict unknown facts with high accuracy [20]; and there is also an improved work on RESCAL [15].

proposed a series of embedding approaches of KB that predict new facts from the existing ones [5, 3, 4]; these approaches embed entities and relations in a KB into a continuous vector space while preserving the original knowledge; new facts are predicted by manipulating vectors and matrices.

metadata.abstractText: Recently, several large-scale RDF knowledge bases have been built and applied in many knowledge-based applications. To further increase the number of facts in RDF knowledge bases, logic rules can be used to predict new facts based on the existing ones. Therefore, how to automatically learn reliable rules from large-scale knowledge bases becomes increasingly important. In this paper, we propose a novel rule learning approach named RDF2Rules for RDF knowledge bases. RDF2Rules first mines frequent predicate cycles (FPCs), a kind of interesting frequent patterns in knowledge bases, and then generates rules from the mined FPCs. Because each FPC can produce multiple rules, and effective pruning strategy is used in the process of mining FPCs, RDF2Rules works very efficiently. Another advantage of RDF2Rules is that it uses the entity type information when generates and evaluates rules, which makes the learned rules more accurate. Experiments show that our approach outperforms the compared approach in terms of both efficiency and accuracy.
